overview.label: Flagship Project
overview.title: TRANSACT: Transparency in Action
overview.tagline: Measuring the gap between FOI law on paper and FOI law in practice
paragraphs: TRANSACT is a large-scale research project that measures the gap between formal adoption of Freedom of Information laws and their actual implementation. Using a controlled experimental protocol, we sent FOI requests to all 581 municipalities in Belgium using five different requester profiles — from ordinary citizens to university professors and civil society organisations. Each municipality was randomly assigned one treatment, stratified by region and population size. Responses were coded on a five-point scale from no reply to complete disclosure.

The project mobilised 36 graduate students from the “Innovations in Policy Evaluation” course at ULB as citizen scientists. They sent requests, managed responses, and coded outcomes under strict non-disclosure protocols — generating one of the most comprehensive empirical pictures of FOI implementation in Europe.

methodology.title: Experimental Design
methodology.description: FOI requests are standardised across a controlled set of requester profiles. Each administration is randomly assigned one treatment, stratified by region and population size, to ensure causal identification.

methodology.title: Citizen Science Deployment
methodology.description: Graduate students and civil society members send requests, manage responses, and code outcomes. Participants are organised into groups with defined roles and follow non-disclosure protocols.

methodology.title: Response Coding
methodology.description: Every response is classified on a five-point scale: no reply, denial, unsatisfactory reply, partial reply, or complete reply. The coding framework is adapted from Worthy, John, and Vannoni (2017, J-PART).

methodology.title: Computational Text Analysis
methodology.description: For platform data, we apply a full NLP pipeline: HTML cleaning, tokenisation, TF-IDF filtering, lemmatisation, LDA topic modeling (K=6), and sentiment analysis using the FEEL lexicon for French.

methodology.title: Statistical Modeling
methodology.description: Multinomial logistic regression predicts outcomes (successful, not successful, asleep) as a function of topic, accountability-seeking potential, sentiment, request complexity, and administrative type.

profiles.label: Common citizen
profiles.description: standard request, no mention of FOI law

profiles.label: Citizen + FOI
profiles.description: standard citizen citing the legal right of access

profiles.label: Professor
profiles.description: request signed by a university professor

profiles.label: Professor + FOI
profiles.description: academic status combined with legal citation

findings.title: The Silence Problem
findings.description: More than a third of Belgian municipalities did not respond to FOI requests at all, regardless of who was asking. The legal right of access exists on paper but not always in practice.

findings.title: The Expertise Paradox
findings.description: Counter-intuitively, requesters perceived as more knowledgeable about FOI rights — professors, civil society actors, those citing the law — faced greater resistance. Administrations appear more cautious with informed requesters.

findings.title: Regional Disparities
findings.description: Compliance varied sharply across Belgium’s three regions: Brussels achieved ~58% response rates, Flanders ~46%, and Wallonia only ~21%. Larger municipalities consistently outperformed smaller ones.

findings.title: Selective Transparency
findings.description: Requests with higher accountability-seeking potential (policing, internal deliberations, procurement) are significantly less likely to receive any response. Administrations appear risk-averse on sensitive topics.

findings.title: Tone Matters
findings.description: Positive communication tone consistently increases the likelihood of administrative engagement. How you ask matters as much as what you ask for.

findings.title: Complexity Barrier
findings.description: Longer, more complex requests are significantly less likely to result in successful disclosure. Simplicity and clarity improve citizen outcomes in FOI interactions.

expansion.description: Replicating TRANSACT across cantonal and municipal FOI systems in Switzerland’s unique federal structure. Partnered with the University of Lausanne and Loitransparence.ch.
Examining FOI transparency in a post-transition European context. Testing whether post-communist administrative cultures produce distinct patterns of responsiveness.
Applying TRANSACT methodology in a Global South context through collaboration with the University of the Witwatersrand (Wits), Johannesburg.
East African field experiment partner via Makerere University, Kampala. Extending the comparative framework to Sub-Saharan Africa’s diverse administrative environments.
